questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of a painful swelling of the left labium. She also reports some pain while sitting and walking. She is sexually active with one male partner and reports pain during vaginal intercourse. She has no history of serious illness. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a tender, fluctuant mass surrounded by edema and erythema in the left inner labium. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sitz baths are used to treat Bartholin gland cysts. Clinical findings of Bartholin gland cysts include a nontender, unilateral palpable mass in the posterior vaginal introitus that can occasionally cause dyspareunia. However, this patient reports a tender mass, making a Bartholin gland abscess more likely.
Image Description:

Vaginal introitus of a woman presenting with painless swelling of her right labia

There is a small fluid-filled cyst visible as a translucent gray mass at the posterolateral aspect (8 o'clock position) of the vaginal introitus, distending the right labia minora. There are no signs of inflammation.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is used in the treatment of vulvar and vaginal warts. It is a simple procedure performed in the office using local anesthesia. Although genital warts may be tender, they are usually asymptomatic and manifest as exophytic, cauliflower-like lesions.
Image Description:

Confluent nodular, verrucous “cauliflower-like” lesions are visible on the entire labia and the anogenital region.

These findings are characteristic of Condylomata acuminata, which are mostly caused by infection with HPV types 6 and 11.

C) CORRECT:

Incision and drainage (I&D) are indicated for patients with no prior history of a Bartholin gland abscess. Additional management to facilitate drainage (i.e., placement of a Word catheter) may be necessary if the abscess is ≥ 3 cm in size. Catheter placement may not be possible with smaller abscesses and, therefore, supportive treatment with Sitz baths and warm compresses for the inflammation can be used in addition to I&D. Bartholin gland abscesses are usually polymicrobial infections, often involving Escherichia coli. Antibiotics are only required if I&D is unsuccessful, there is a recurrence (≥ 2 episodes) or a high risk of complicated infection, or the patient has a confirmed MRSA infection or signs of systemic infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of a suspected Bartholin gland cyst is indicated if there are any features suggestive of malignancy, such as a progressive, solid, painless mass or a lack of response to treatment, or if the patient has risk factors for malignancy, such as age > 40 years or history of labial malignancy. However, this patient does not have risk factors or features suggestive of malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Marsupialization is indicated for the treatment of recurrent Bartholin gland abscesses; however, this patient does not have a history of Bartholin gland abscesses.

F) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole may be used in the treatment of vulvar abscesses such as Bartholin gland abscesses. However, antibiotic therapy is only required if first-line management is unsuccessful, there is a recurrence (≥ 2 episodes) or a high risk of complicated infection, or the patient has a confirmed MRSA infection or signs of systemic infection.
questions.hint: A Bartholin gland abscess can manifest with acute, unilateral pain and tender swelling in the inner labium. Patients with a Bartholin gland abscess often have dyspareunia and pain with movement.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-day history of discomfort in her vaginal area during and after sexual intercourse. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Two years ago, she was diagnosed with genital herpes which was treated with acyclovir. She has been in a monogamous relationship for the past year and has been using an intrauterine device for contraception for the past month. Examination shows a 4-cm, mildly tender, mobile mass in the inferior aspect of the left labium minus with no signs of inflammation. Speculum examination causes her discomfort but shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Obstructed orifice of the Bartholin duct
Obstructed orifice of a sebaceous gland
Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva
Allergic reaction to the intrauterine device
Obstructed orifice of the Skene gland
Prolapse of the distal urethral mucosa

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Obstruction of the orifice of Bartholin gland duct by inflammation or trauma results in the formation of a palpable mass in the posterior vaginal introitus (Bartholin gland cyst), which can cause mild dyspareunia. Bartholin gland cysts are quite common and have a peak incidence at 20–30 years of age. Treatment of Bartholin gland cyst primarily involves Sitz baths to encourage spontaneous drainage of the cyst. Surgery can be considered for recurrent or infected cysts (Bartholin gland abscess).

B) INCORRECT:

In the female external genitalia, sebaceous glands only occur on the labia majora, labia minora, and the prepuce. Occlusion of the orifices of the sebaceous glands results in Fordyce spots, which are pinhead-sized, yellow-white, symmetrically distributed spots unlike the single, 4-cm mass on the inferior aspect of the left labium. Furthermore, Fordyce spots are asymptomatic unlike the lesion in this patient which results in dyspareunia and vaginal discomfort.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of genital herpes would result in acute dyspareunia. However, unlike in this patient, the condition also presents with multiple, erythematous lesions over the labia, vagina, clitoris, and cervix that progress to vesicles and then to shallow ulcers that heal with crusting. The degree of vaginal discomfort is usually far greater and most patients would have systemic symptoms such as headache, malaise, and/or fever.
Image Description:

The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.

These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

D) INCORRECT:

A squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulvar carcinoma (90% of cases) and can result in vaginal discomfort and dyspareunia, but the most common sites for a vulval carcinoma are the anterior two-thirds of the labia majora followed by the clitoris. The lesion is typically ulceroproliferative with raised everted edges and surrounding induration, and patients often have a history of chronic pruritic vulva preceding the appearance of the lesion. SCC is unlikely in this patient with a 6-day history of vaginal discomfort and a 4-cm, tender mass in the posterior region of the left labium minus.

E) INCORRECT:

A local allergic reaction to an intrauterine device would result in dyspareunia and vaginal excoriation with vulvar edema. However, vulvar edema would occur bilaterally and other symptoms such as vaginal discharge would be present.

F) INCORRECT:

Genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder (vaginismus) can only be diagnosed in the absence of any organic cause for dyspareunia. The mass in the left labium of this patient indicates an organic cause for this patient's symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the orifice of the Skene gland can result in the formation of Skene duct cysts, which are typically small (< 1 cm), asymptomatic periurethral cysts. Large Skene duct cysts or infected Skene duct cysts may result in dyspareunia, but would not present with a tender mass in the inferior aspect of the left labium minus.

H) INCORRECT:

A prolapse of the distal urethral mucosa is referred to as a urethral caruncle. A urethral caruncle would result in dyspareunia, but it appears as a small (< 0.5 cm), pedunculated, reddish mass protruding out of the urethral meatus rather than the 4-cm tender mass in the posterior region of the left labia minora in this patient. Also, a urethral caruncle occurs almost exclusively among postmenopausal women and would be associated with other symptoms such as dysuria and irregular vaginal bleeding.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a mass that is characteristically found only at the four and eight o'clock positions of the vestibule of the vagina.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Pelvic examination shows a pink, 2 x 2-cm, fluctuant swelling at the right posterior vaginal introitus. The swelling is most likely derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma, which is the most common type of vulvar carcinoma (90% of cases), arises from the epithelium of the vulva. The most common sites for vulvar carcinoma are the anterior two-thirds of the labia major, followed by the clitoris. The lesion typically presents as an indurated white patch (leukoplakia) or an ulceroproliferative lesion. A pink fluctuant swelling in the posterior introitus is not consistent with vulvar carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the orifice of the paraurethral glands (Skene glands) results in the formation of Skene ducts cysts, which are typically small (< 1 cm) and do not cause any symptoms. Unlike this patient's palpable mass in the area of the posterior vaginal introitus, skene glands are located on the anterior vaginal wall, close to the opening of the urethra.

C) CORRECT:

This woman in the reproductive age group most likely has a cystic dilatation of the greater vestibular glands (Bartholin glands), which are located at the posterior vaginal introitus in the superficial perineal pouch. Obstruction of the orifice of the Bartholin gland duct by inflammation or trauma results in the formation of a Bartholin cyst. Infection of the Bartholin cyst (Bartholin abscess) would result in a tender swelling and severe dyspareunia.

D) INCORRECT:

A Gartner duct cyst originates from a vestigial remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) and can present as a palpable vaginal mass. However, a Gartner duct cyst is typically found in the anterolateral wall of the superior part of the vagina, unlike this patient's swelling, which is located in the posterior vaginal introitus.

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the orifices of the sebaceous glands results in Fordyce spots, which are pinhead-sized, yellowish-white spots distributed symmetrically on the labia. The finding in this patient is not consistent with Fordyce spots.
questions.hint: A mass located posterolaterally at the vaginal introitus suggests a Bartholin cyst.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. Medical history is remarkable for uncomplicated gonorrhea treated with ceftriaxone 4 years ago. Her only medication is a plant-based sleeping aid. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms consistently. She works as a nurse. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a single, 2-cm in diameter, nontender, mobile mass in the lower vestibule of the vagina. Speculum examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Observation is the preferred management option for patients with a small (≤ 3 cm), asymptomatic Bartholin gland cyst. Warm compresses or sitz baths may be used to promote rupture and drainage of a cyst. Larger Bartholin gland cysts (> 3 cm) or symptomatic cysts with abscess formation should be managed with incision and drainage, followed by marsupialization or placement of a Word catheter. A biopsy of the mass should be performed if a patient has risk factors (e.g., age > 40 years, history of labial malignancy) or features suggestive of malignancy (e.g., solid component within the cyst, no response to treatment).
Image Description:

Vaginal introitus of a woman presenting with painless swelling of her right labia

There is a small fluid-filled cyst visible as a translucent gray mass at the posterolateral aspect (8 o'clock position) of the vaginal introitus, distending the right labia minora. There are no signs of inflammation.

B) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of a Bartholin gland cyst is indicated if features suggestive of malignancy are present, such as a solid component within the cyst, attachment to the surrounding tissue, cyst persistence or worsening despite treatment or if the patient has risk factors for malignancy, such as age > 40 years or a history of labial malignancy. This patient currently has a small (≤ 3 cm), asymptomatic Bartholin gland cyst with no risk factors for malignancy, making a different approach more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

A Word catheter is placed after incision and drainage of a Bartholin gland abscess or a large (> 3 cm), symptomatic Bartholin gland cyst. The catheter is left in situ for several weeks to facilitate drainage and allow for reepithelialization. This patient is asymptomatic and has a small Bartholin gland cyst that is 2 cm in diameter, making another approach more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is the definitive treatment for Bartholin gland carcinoma or Bartholin cysts that do not resolve despite less invasive measures. This patient currently has a small, asymptomatic Bartholin gland cyst with no risk factors or features suggesting malignancy, making a different approach more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is indicated in patients with a large Bartholin gland cyst (> 3 cm) or a Bartholin gland abscess. Symptoms of a Bartholin gland abscess typically include swelling and severe pain, which can make walking, sitting, or sexual intercourse intolerable. This patient is asymptomatic and has a small Bartholin gland cyst that is 2 cm in diameter, making another approach more appropriate.
questions.hint: A small, nontender, mobile mass in the lower vestibule of the vagina is consistent with a Bartholin gland cyst.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a four-day history of a painful swelling near her vaginal opening. She reports that it has gradually enlarged and now causes significant discomfort when walking. She does not report any high-risk sexual behaviors. Examination reveals a tender, fluctuant mass in the lower lateral region of the labium with surrounding erythema. Palpation elicits marked pain.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bartholin duct abscess manifests as a tender, fluctuant mass in the lower lateral labial region, often with surrounding erythema. The Bartholin glands, located bilaterally at the vaginal introitus, secrete mucus for lubrication. Obstruction of the duct can lead to bacterial colonization and abscess formation, particularly in sexually active women in their twenties and thirties. The gradual onset of pain and swelling is due to purulent material accumulation from impaired drainage. The anatomical location and inflammatory response observed during examination support the diagnosis of a Bartholin duct abscess.

Key learning point: A painful, red, and tender swelling on the vulva at the 4 or 8 o'clock position is characteristic of a Bartholin duct abscess, caused by infection of the Bartholin gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Vulvar carcinoma typically presents as a firm, indurated mass over a prolonged period in older women. The rapid onset of a tender, fluctuant mass with erythema suggests an inflammatory process. The absence of risk factors, such as high-risk sexual behaviors, further reduces the likelihood of vulvar carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Gartner duct cysts arise from mesonephric duct remnants and typically present along the lateral vaginal wall, not the lower lateral labium. They are usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. The acute presentation with tenderness, fluctuance, and erythema suggests an inflammatory process, inconsistent with the benign nature of Gartner duct cysts.

D) INCORRECT:

Skene glands, or paraurethral glands, are located near the urethral meatus on the anterior vulva, not the lateral labia. The absence of urinary symptoms and the anatomical location of the mass make a Skene gland abscess unlikely. The described mass's location and characteristics do not align with Skene gland involvement.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. She reports feeling well. Her medical history includes uncomplicated gonorrhea treated with ceftriaxone 4 years ago. Her only medication is a plant-based sleeping aid. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms consistently. She works as a nurse. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mm Hg. On examination, you find a single, 2-cm, nontender, mobile mass in the lower vestibule of the vagina. Speculum examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Observation is the preferred management option for patients with a small (≤ 3 cm), asymptomatic Bartholin gland cyst. Warm compresses or sitz baths may be used to promote rupture and drainage of a cyst. Larger Bartholin gland cysts (> 3 cm) or symptomatic cysts with abscess formation should be managed with incision and drainage, followed by marsupialization or placement of a Word catheter. A biopsy of the mass should be performed if a patient has risk factors (e.g., age > 40 years, history of labial malignancy) or features suggestive of malignancy (e.g., solid component within the cyst, no response to treatment).

Key learning point: Small, asymptomatic Bartholin gland cysts should be managed with observation and supportive care, reserving intervention for larger, symptomatic, or suspicious lesions.
Image Description:

Vaginal introitus of a woman presenting with painless swelling of her right labia

There is a small fluid-filled cyst visible as a translucent gray mass at the posterolateral aspect (8 o'clock position) of the vaginal introitus, distending the right labia minora. There are no signs of inflammation.

B) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of a Bartholin gland cyst is indicated if features suggestive of malignancy are present, such as a solid component within the cyst, attachment to the surrounding tissue, cyst persistence or worsening despite treatment or if the patient has risk factors for malignancy, such as age > 40 years or a history of labial malignancy. This patient currently has a small (≤ 3 cm), asymptomatic Bartholin gland cyst with no risk factors for malignancy, making a different approach more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

A Word catheter is placed after incision and drainage of a Bartholin gland abscess or a large (> 3 cm), symptomatic Bartholin gland cyst. The catheter is left in situ for several weeks to facilitate drainage and allow for reepithelialization. This patient is asymptomatic and has a small Bartholin gland cyst that is 2 cm in diameter, making another approach more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is indicated in patients with a large Bartholin gland cyst (> 3 cm) or a Bartholin gland abscess. Symptoms of a Bartholin gland abscess typically include swelling and severe pain, which can make walking, sitting, or sexual intercourse intolerable. This patient is asymptomatic and has a small Bartholin gland cyst that is 2 cm in diameter, making another approach more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is the definitive treatment for Bartholin gland carcinoma or Bartholin cysts that do not resolve despite less invasive measures. This patient currently has a small, asymptomatic Bartholin gland cyst with no risk factors or features suggesting malignancy, making a different approach more appropriate at this time.
questions.hint: A small, nontender, mobile mass in the lower vestibule of the vagina is consistent with a Bartholin gland cyst.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of painful swelling of the left labium. She also reports pain while sitting, walking, and during vaginal intercourse. She is sexually active with one male partner and has no history of serious illness. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.9°C, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, there is a tender, fluctuant mass with surrounding edema and erythema in the left inner labium. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A) INCORRECT:

Marsupialization is indicated for the treatment of recurrent Bartholin gland abscesses; however, this patient does not have a history of Bartholin gland abscesses.

B) INCORRECT:

E) CORRECT:

Incision and drainage (I&D) are indicated for patients with no prior history of a Bartholin gland abscess. Catheter placement may not be possible with smaller abscesses and, therefore, supportive treatment with Sitz baths and warm compresses for the inflammation can be used in addition to I&D. Bartholin gland abscesses are usually polymicrobial infections, often involving Escherichia coli. Antibiotics are only required if I&D is unsuccessful, there is a recurrence (≥ 2 episodes) or a high risk of complicated infection, or the patient has a confirmed MRSA infection or signs of systemic infection.

Key learning point: The initial management of a Bartholin gland abscess is incision and drainage, with antibiotics reserved for recurrent, complicated, or treatment-resistant cases.

questions.hint: This patient presents with a mass that is characteristically found only at the four and eight o'clock positions of the vestibule of the vagina.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of progressive vulvar discomfort and dyspareunia. Physical examination shows a 4 cm unilateral mass that is tender and fluctuant with surrounding erythema and located at the 4 o'clock position of the vaginal opening. She is afebrile and denies purulent discharge. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Incision and drainage is indicated for all Bartholin gland abscesses. The placement of a Word catheter facilitates drainage and allows for reepithelialization.

B) INCORRECT:

Needle aspiration is not recommended for Bartholin gland abscesses because it does not provide adequate drainage and has high recurrence rates.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are insufficient for managing Bartholin gland abscesses unless incision and drainage is unsuccessful.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with sitz baths is appropriate for smaller, asymptomatic Bartholin gland cysts ≤ 3 cm, but not for Bartholin gland abscesses.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with a Bartholin gland abscess and requires timely management rather than outpatient referral.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with severe, worsening right-sided vulvar pain and swelling over the past three days, making it difficult for her to sit or walk. She denies any fever, chills, or vaginal discharge. She has a history of a small, non-tender lump in the same area a year ago that resolved spontaneously. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Pelvic examination reveals a 4-cm, exquisitely tender, erythematous, and fluctuant mass at the 5 o'clock position of the right labia majora. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform needle aspiration of the abscess
Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement
Prescribe a course of oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Recommend warm sitz baths and oral analgesics
Surgical excision of the Bartholin gland

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Needle aspiration may seem like a less invasive way to drain the abscess. However, it is associated with a very high rate of treatment failure and recurrence for Bartholin gland abscesses. The purulent material is often too thick to be fully evacuated with a needle, and the puncture site closes quickly, allowing the abscess to re-form.

B) CORRECT:

The definitive management for a symptomatic Bartholin gland abscess is incision and drainage (I&D). Placement of a Word catheter after drainage is crucial to prevent premature closure of the incision, allowing for continued drainage and the formation of an epithelialized tract (a process called fistulization). The catheter is typically left in place for 4-6 weeks. This procedure provides immediate symptom relief and reduces the high rate of recurrence associated with simple I&D alone. Antibiotics are typically reserved for patients with significant surrounding cellulitis, systemic signs of infection, or those who are immunocompromised.

C) INCORRECT:

While Bartholin gland abscesses are bacterial infections, oral antibiotics alone are not sufficient treatment for a mature, fluctuant abscess. The primary treatment requires drainage of the purulent collection. Antibiotics may be used as an adjunct to drainage in cases of significant cellulitis, systemic infection, or in high-risk patients, but they are not the sole or primary management.

D) INCORRECT:

Warm sitz baths and analgesics are appropriate management for a small, non-infected, asymptomatic or mildly tender Bartholin duct cyst. This patient, however, has a 4-cm, exquisitely tender, fluctuant mass, indicating a developed abscess. Conservative measures are insufficient at this stage and will not resolve the infection or provide adequate pain relief.

E) INCORRECT:

Excision of the gland is a definitive treatment but is reserved for recurrent Bartholin gland abscesses or cysts that have failed less invasive management. It is not the first-line treatment for an initial abscess due to increased risks of bleeding and morbidity, especially when performed in an acutely inflamed and infected field.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features of a tender, fluctuant, erythematous mass at the posterolateral vaginal introitus are suggestive of a Bartholin gland abscess.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to an urgent care clinic with a 3-day history of a painful, enlarging mass on her right labia, which is exacerbated by walking and sitting. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, tender, fluctuant, and erythematous mass located at the 5 o'clock position of the vaginal introitus. This patient's condition is most likely caused by the obstruction of a duct originating from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The greater vestibular glands, also known as Bartholin glands, are located bilaterally at the 4 and 8 o'clock positions of the vaginal vestibule. Their primary function is to secrete mucus for lubrication. Duct obstruction leads to mucus accumulation, forming a cyst. If this cyst becomes infected, typically by polymicrobial vaginal or enteric flora, it develops into a painful abscess. Management involves incision and drainage, often with placement of a Word catheter to promote continued drainage and prevent recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

The lesser vestibular glands, also known as Skene glands, are located paraurethrally and drain into the distal urethra. While obstruction can lead to a cyst or abscess, the resulting mass would be located anteriorly, adjacent to the urethral meatus, not at the 5 o'clock position of the posterior vaginal introitus.

C) INCORRECT:

Gartner ducts are embryologic remnants of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct. Cysts arising from these structures are typically located on the anterolateral wall of the upper vagina, not at the introitus. They are usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on pelvic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Nabothian glands are mucus-secreting glands located on the surface of the cervix. When their ducts become blocked, they form benign retention cysts called Nabothian cysts. These are confined to the cervix and would not present as a mass on the labia or at the vaginal introitus.

E) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous glands are present throughout the hair-bearing skin of the labia majora and can form cysts or abscesses if they become blocked. However, the specific location at the 5 o'clock position of the vaginal introitus is highly characteristic of a different gland.
questions.hint: The clinical presentation of a unilateral, tender, fluctuant, and erythematous mass at the posterolateral vaginal introitus is consistent with a Bartholin gland abscess.
